title: Who were the victims of Edmund Kemper and where is he now?
text:
Serial killer Ed Kemper murdered 10 people between 1964 and 1973

American serial killer Edmund Emil Kemper III, known as the ‘Co-Ed killer’, was found guilty of 10 counts of murder between 1964 and 1973.

His victims included his grandparents and his mother and her best friend.

Kemper also murdered six students – raping, murdering and decapitating his victims.

He would pick up and kill female students who were hitchhiking, taking them back to his home and perform sex acts on their dismembered bodies.

Kemper, who is 6ft, 9 in tall, was convicted in 1973 and received eight life sentences.

True crime documentary Kemper On Kemper, is fronted by former FBI agent John Douglas who details his extensive and chilling interviews with Kemper.

But who were his victims?

Ed Kemper was known as the ‘Co-Ed killer’ (Picture: Getty)

Maude Matilda Hughey Kemper and Edmund Emil Kemper

Maude and Edmund were Kemper’s grandparents who he fatally shot when he was just 15-years-old.

Advertisement

He shot his grandmother after an argument, before killing his grandfather in the driveway so he wouldn’t have to learn his wife was dead.

Kemper’s grandmother Maude

Kemper shot and killed his grandfather Edmund Emil Kemper

He was sent to a maximum security facility for the criminally insane and granted parole when he was 21.

Mary Ann Pesce and Anita Luchessa

Mary Ann and Anita were both hitchhiking in 1972 when they were picked up by Kemper, who said he would take them to Standford University.

In a secluded wood he stabbed and strangled both teenagers to death before driving back to his apartment with both of their bodies in the trunk.

Anita’s remains have not been found

He had sex with their naked corpses before beheading them.

He abandoned their bodies in plastic bags which he abandoned near Loma Preita Mountain.

Mary Ann’s skull was discovered in 2017 and Anita’s body has not been found.

Mary Ann Pesce was hitchhiking when she was picked up by Kemper

Aiko Koo

Aiko was a 15-year-old dance student who decided to hitchhike to a dance class.

Kemper picked her up then choked her unconscious before raping and killing her, dismembering her body and disposing of it.

Cindy Shall

Kemper picked up 19-year-old Cindy near Watsonville in 1973 and shot her in the trunk of his car.

He took her corpse back to his apartment and had intercourse with her body before dismembering her and burying her head in his mother’s garden.

Rosalind Thorpe and Allison Liu

Kemper met Rosalind, 23, and Allison, 20, on the campus of University of California Santa Cruz in 1973. He managed to lure them into his car as he had a university sticker displayed on his car which he had procured from his mother.

When they entered his car, he fatally shot them and wrapped their bodies in blankets in his trunk.

Kemper murdered Allison Liu in 1973

Rosalind Thorpe was just 23 when she was murdered by Kemper

When he got back to his mother’s home he beheaded the bodies, and the next morning he had sex with Alice’s body in his room. He brought it Rosalind’s head to remove the bullet that was lodged in it then drove away from Santa Cruz to dispose of the remains.

Clarnell Strandberg and Sally Hallett

In 1973 he murdered his mother Clarnell with a claw hammer while she slept before decapitating her and raping her severed head.

He then invited his mother’s best friend Sally round to his mother’s house where he also killed her, as he felt attention would be drawn away from him if more than one person was found dead in the house.

Kemper killed his mother Charnell and her best friend

Stealing her car he drove to Colorado and called the police from a phone booth to confess to murdering his mother.

Advertisement

At first he had to convince police it wasn’t a prank call, then he helped guide the police to his location.

When he was in custody he recounted the murders in explicit detail.

Where is Ed Kemper now?

He was found guilty of first degree murder on 8 November 1973 and was sent to a maximum security prison for life.

Kemper is still behind bars serving his eight life sentences in the California Medical Facility.

His half-brother David Weber, an alias he uses to protect his identity, has spoken in the past about how he fears Kemper will be released from prison.

He told Dailymail.com: ‘I think he manipulates everyone. I think that he has never told anyone the truth about things he has done. I would suspect he is holding back a good 20 to 30 per cent of the truth about himself, his past, and how he thinks.

‘All I know is that he gets to live better there [prison] than most people on the streets. Free gym, free food, free housekeeping. Thanks to liberals, he has it good.

‘Personally, I hope he chokes. If he came around to my family, I’d shoot him on sight.’

Kemper On Kemper is available now on Sky Crime and NOWTV.
